questions.text:
A 59-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by his wife because of a 3-day history of worsening shortness of breath. He has a history of long-standing hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. Current medications include enalapril, amlodipine, and metformin. His wife reports that he only takes his medications every second or third day. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 30 years. He stopped drinking alcohol 3 years ago. His temperature is 37.1°C (98.9°F), pulse is 86/min, and blood pressure is 167/95 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 91%. Pulmonary examination is shown. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
Video
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Oral metoprolol can be used in the treatment of hypertension, especially in patients with concomitant heart failure. However, metoprolol should be avoided in patients with acute decompensated heart failure, which this patient most likely has, as this drug decreases myocardial contractility, resulting in left ventricular dysfunction and further worsening of pulmonary edema.

B) INCORRECT:

Inhaled albuterol and corticosteroids are typically indicated in patients with respiratory distress due to obstructive lung disease (e.g., asthma, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease). This type of condition manifests with wheezing and rhonchi, not the bibasilar lung crackles heard in this patient.

C) CORRECT:

This patient presents with respiratory distress (acute dyspnea, hypoxemia) and bibasilar crackles on pulmonary auscultation. In conjunction with his history of long-standing, poorly controlled hypertension, these findings indicate pulmonary edema due to acute decompensated heart failure (ADHF). As this patient is hemodynamically stable, management includes oxygen supplementation, proper positioning (raising the head of the bed), and intravenous loop diuretics such as furosemide. Diuresis results in a decrease in intravascular volume, thereby reducing the cardiac preload, central venous pressure, and pulmonary capillary wedge pressure, which, in turn, reduces pulmonary edema. Furthermore, in patients with pulmonary edema, furosemide causes transient venodilation, further reducing pulmonary congestion, even before the onset of diuresis. If respiratory distress persists, treatment with vasodilators for ADHF (e.g., nitroglycerin) may be initiated to further reduce preload.

For the appropriate management of ADHF, think LMNOP: Loop diuretics (furosemide), Modify medications, Nitrates, Oxygen if hypoxic, Position (with elevated upper body).

D) INCORRECT:

Chest tube placement is indicated in patients with pneumothorax, hemothorax, or pleural effusion. Although this patient presents with symptoms associated with these conditions (dyspnea, hypoxemia), auscultation would typically reveal decreased breath sounds rather than the bibasilar crackles heard in this patient.

E) INCORRECT:

Antibiotics may be indicated for patients with respiratory distress due to pneumonia. This condition, however, typically manifests with unilateral crackles, fever, pleuritic chest pain, and productive cough rather than the bibasilar lung crackles that are heard in this patient.

F) INCORRECT:

Intravenous corticosteroids are administered in patients with respiratory distress due to acute exacerbation of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (AECOPD). Although this patient has a long-standing smoking history, which puts him at increased risk for COPD, auscultation would reveal wheezing or rhonchi, not the bibasilar lung crackles heard here. AECOPD classically manifests with increasing frequency or severity of cough, and/or increasing volume or purulence of sputum.

questions.text:
A 68-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of a 1-week history of worsening bouts of shortness of breath at night. He has had a cough for 1 month occasionally productive of frothy sputum. He has type 2 diabetes mellitus and long-standing hypertension. Two years ago, he was diagnosed with Paget disease of bone during a routine health maintenance examination. He has smoked a pack of cigarettes daily for 20 years. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 110/min, respirations are 25/min, and blood pressure is 145/98 mm Hg. Current medications include metformin, alendronate, hydrochlorothiazide, and enalapril. Physical examination shows bibasilar crackles. Cardiac examination shows a dull, low-pitched sound during late diastole that is best heard at the apex. There is no jugular venous distention or peripheral edema. Arterial blood gas analysis on room air shows:


pH
7.46


PCO2

29 mm Hg


PO2

83 mm Hg


HCO3-

20 mEq/L


Echocardiography shows a left ventricular ejection fraction of 55%. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient’s current condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Destruction of alveolar walls is the pathophysiologic hallmark of emphysema, a subtype of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), which would match the history of long-term smoking, shortness of breath, and productive cough. But for COPD, reduced lung sounds would be expected on auscultation. In addition, COPD would not explain this patient's S4 heart sound. Lastly, the CO2 retention that is associated with COPD leads to respiratory acidosis, not alkalosis.

B) INCORRECT:

Decreased myocardial contractility is the pathophysiologic mechanism of heart failure with reduced ejection fraction (HFrEF), which commonly occurs after myocardial infarction (MI) or due to dilated cardiomyopathy. However, this patient's cardiac output is preserved, as is evident in his LVEF of 55%. In addition, despite this patient having risk factors for coronary artery disease (diabetes mellitus, hypertension, older age), he has no clinical features or history to suggest an MI.
Image Description:

Reduced cardiac output results in the activation of compensatory mechanisms (i.e., ADH and BNP production, activation of the renin-angiotensin system and sympathetic nervous system) in an attempt to restore cardiac output.

Cardiac remodeling and increases in afterload both have a negative effect on cardiac output. Increases in heart rate and preload have a positive effect on cardiac output. The net effect of these compensatory mechanisms may be sufficient to restore cardiac output. If not, the cycle repeats.

C) INCORRECT:

Diuretic overdose manifests as a contraction alkalosis characterized by volume depletion, which in turn activates the RAAS system. The renal changes caused by the aldosterone effect in the renal tubule (sodium reabsorption, potassium and hydrogen excretion) result in metabolic alkalosis, not respiratory alkalosis. Additionally, this patient does not have notable signs of volume depletion like thirst, decreased skin turgor, or dry mucous membranes.

D) INCORRECT:

Myxomatous degeneration is the most common pathophysiologic cause of mitral valve prolapse (MVP). Although severe MVP could eventually lead to heart failure and pulmonary venous congestion due to increased left atrial pressure, this patient does not have typical features of MVP like chest pain, palpitations, and a high-frequency, midsystolic click that is best heard in the mitral region.

E) INCORRECT:

Because this patient was recently diagnosed with Paget disease of the bone, he is at increased risk of developing systemic arteriovenous fistulas, which can result in high output cardiac failure. This rare complication is caused by the increased vascularity within the abnormal bone that is undergoing high rates of remodeling. High-output cardiac failure manifests with features of hyperdynamic circulation such as high pulse pressure, bounding pulses with a quick upstroke, subungual capillary pulsations, and venous hums, none of which is present in this patient.

F) CORRECT:

Chronic uncontrolled hypertension is the most common cause of HFpEF. Chronic hypertension increases the afterload against which the left ventricle (LV) contracts. As a compensatory mechanism, the myocardium undergoes concentric hypertrophy to maintain cardiac output. Over time, the compensatory response of LV thickening is associated with the maladaptive change of interstitial myocardial fibrosis, which leads to an increase in LV stiffness and impaired myocardial relaxation. As a result, patients develop an increase in left ventricular filling pressures and reduced ventricular filling with normal ventricular contraction (i.e., diastolic dysfunction). Severe myocardial fibrosis can ultimately impair myocardial contractility and result in systolic dysfunction but in such a scenario, the patient will have a low ejection fraction.

Note that impaired myocardial relaxation could have also been correct for restrictive cardiomyopathy, in which the ventricular walls harden without myocardial hypertrophy.
questions.hint: This patient has features of acute left heart failure, including paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea, a cough productive of frothy sputum, an S4 heart sound (low frequency, late diastolic sound) and bibasilar crackles (suggesting pulmonary edema), and a left ventricular ejection fraction (LVEF) of 55%, all of which are consistent with heart failure with preserved ejection fraction (HFpEF). The ABG shows compensated primary respiratory alkalosis, likely due to hyperventilation.

questions.text: The serum brain natriuretic peptide and N-terminal pro-BNP are elevated. A diagnosis of heart failure with preserved ejection fraction is made. In addition to supplemental oxygen therapy, which of the following is the most appropriate initial step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Oral statins such as atorvastatin are indicated in patients with congestive heart failure in which ischemic heart disease is the cause of myocardial dysfunction. While this patient has risk factors for atherosclerotic disease such as type 2 diabetes mellitus and long-standing hypertension, he lacks evidence of coronary artery disease (e.g., retrosternal chest pain/pressure, dyspnea, dizziness). Moreover, statins are only indicated in the long-term management of congestive heart failure, not in an acute setting.

B) INCORRECT:

Oral beta blockers (e.g., metoprolol) are typically reserved for long-term management of congestive heart failure, not in an acute setting, since their negative inotropic effect can worsen cardiac output. Beta-blocker therapy should be considered once the volume status of the patient has improved.

C) INCORRECT:

Hemodialysis is indicated in patients with congestive heart failure with volume overload that is refractory to aggressive diuresis with multiple agents, especially if they have increasing oxygen requirements. It is also indicated in patients who develop kidney failure due to cardiogenic shock. This patient has only been treated with hydrochlorothiazide thus far. Moreover, he does not have signs of kidney failure (e.g., oliguria, metabolic acidosis, uremia).

D) INCORRECT:

Opiates such as morphine can reduce patient anxiety and the work of breathing by decreasing central sympathetic output. They also cause peripheral vasodilation and venodilation, decreasing ventricular filling pressure. However, there is not enough available evidence regarding the benefits or potential risks associated with morphine administration (e.g., hypopnea, nausea) in patients with congestive heart failure. Therefore, morphine is not considered standard treatment in the management of acute exacerbation of congestive heart failure and would not be the most appropriate initial step in this patient who does not report significant anxiety.

E) INCORRECT:

Thoracentesis is indicated for both diagnostic and therapeutic purposes in patients with pleural effusion. This patient's lung examination findings of bibasilar crackles are inconsistent with a pleural effusion, which typically manifests with decreased breath sounds, dullness to percussion, and decreased tactile fremitus in the affected area due to fluid in the pleural space. Thoracentesis is not indicated in patients with pulmonary edema.

F) INCORRECT:

Inotropes such as dobutamine are mainly used as a short-term measure in patients with congestive heart failure (CHF) and a reduced ejection fraction with evidence of cardiogenic shock, systemic hypoperfusion, and end-organ damage. Inotropes are not recommended for patients with CHF with preserved ejection fraction, as seen in this man.

G) CORRECT:

In addition to supplemental oxygen therapy and ventilatory support as needed, this patient requires IV furosemide therapy to improve his volume overload status. Loop diuretics are a first-line treatment for symptomatic relief in acute exacerbation of congestive heart failure in patients with normal or elevated blood pressure. To assess the response to therapy and prevent excessive diuresis and preload reduction, it is important to monitor for adverse effects such as hypokalemia and hyponatremia as well as weight changes and volume status. Intravenous vasodilators (e.g., nitroglycerine, nitroprusside) can be considered as an adjunct treatment. These agents cause peripheral vasodilation, resulting in pooling of blood in the venous system, which rapidly reduces ventricular filling pressures and improves cardiac function.
questions.hint: In the absence of other life-threatening conditions (e.g., acute coronary syndrome, shock) that require immediate attention, symptomatic treatment of this patient's pulmonary edema should come first in management.

questions.text: A 58-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 5-day history of progressively worsening shortness of breath and fatigue. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 30 years. His pulse is 96/min, respirations are 26/min, and blood pressure is 100/60 mm Hg. An x-ray of the chest is shown. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's findings?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This patient's acute onset dyspnea and CXR findings suggest cardiogenic pulmonary edema due to left ventricular failure. Individuals with left ventricular failure initially develop interstitial edema, which results in smooth reticular opacification and Kerley B lines due to accentuation of the vascular markings. With the further increase in pulmonary capillary wedge pressure, individuals can develop features of alveolar edema (e.g., consolidation with an air bronchogram) and pleural effusion (e.g., blunting of the costophrenic angle). In pulmonary edema, the opacification can often assume a perihilar distribution (a so-called “batwing” or “butterfly-shaped” pattern), which is seen here, because the periphery of the lung has better lymphatic drainage than the central regions.

B) INCORRECT:

Tricuspid regurgitation is a rare valvular condition. It typically manifests with clinical features of right heart failure, such as jugular venous distention, pulsatile hepatomegaly, and pedal edema, none of which are seen here. Moreover, the CXR findings for tricuspid regurgitation typically include right atrial and right ventricular enlargement, unlike the left ventricular enlargement seen on this patient's CXR.
Image Description:

X-ray chest (PA view) of a neonate with Ebstein anomaly

The cardiac silhouette is markedly enlarged. Prominent convexity of the right heart border (green line) is the result of caudal displacement of the tricuspid valve with atrialization of the right ventricle and tricuspid regurgitation. The central pulmonary arteries (green arrowheads) and aortic knob (red arrowhead) are diminutive in appearance. An endotracheal tube is present, along with an umbilical venous catheter and nasogastric tube.

Radiographic findings in Ebstein anomaly may vary with the severity of the condition.

C) INCORRECT:

Spontaneous pneumothorax causes acute onset dyspnea, and a CXR would show a radiolucent region without lung markings (air collection). This patient's CXR findings are inconsistent with a pneumothorax.
Image Description:

Chest x-ray (PA view) of a patient without a history of trauma

A large left pneumothorax (blue overlay) is seen, with an absence of lung markings peripheral to the collapsed lung (yellow overlay). Contralateral shift of the mediastinum (indicated by arrows) has resulted in a prominent right heart border (white line), and there is slight widening of the left lateral costophrenic angle (angle marker). These findings are consistent with tension pneumothorax. Incidentally noted is a mild rotatory curvature of the upper thoracic spine.

The absence of thoracic trauma suggests a spontaneous pneumothorax.

Dashed white line: visceral pleural line; green overlay: spinous process; red overlay: vertebral pedicles

D) INCORRECT:

Acute respiratory distress syndrome can cause dyspnea, and a CXR would show butterfly-shaped perihilar opacification, which is seen here. However, this patient's cardiomegaly suggests a chronic underlying cardiovascular condition and, thus, a cardiac cause for the pulmonary edema.
Image Description:

X-ray chest (AP view) of a patient with adult respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS)

Confluent and multifocal airspace opacities (examples indicated by green overlay) predominate in the lower zones of the lungs. Air bronchograms (examples indicated by red lines) are visible in some locations. There are no Kerley lines or pleural effusions. The cardiac silhouette size is normal. An endotracheal tube (arrow) is present.

ARDS and other causes of noncardiogenic edema can produce extensive airspace opacification, as can cardiogenic edema, diffuse pneumonia, diffuse alveolar hemorrhage, pneumonic-type adenocarcinoma, and pulmonary alveolar proteinosis. Radiography alone cannot establish a diagnosis of ARDS.

E) INCORRECT:

Pulmonary embolism can cause acute onset dyspnea as well as blunting of the costophrenic angle due to a pleural effusion caused by pulmonary infarction. Kerley B lines and butterfly-shaped perihilar opacities would not, however, be seen in pulmonary embolism. The CXR findings associated with pulmonary embolism are relatively nonsensitive and nonspecific and include wedge-shaped pulmonary opacification due to pulmonary infarction, a regional decrease in pulmonary vascular markings, and enlargement of the pulmonary artery, none of which are seen here.
Image Description:

X-ray chest (PA view) of a patient with pleuritic chest pain

A peripheral opacity (Hampton hump; green overlay) obscures the adjacent margin of the right hemidiaphragm. A Hampton hump is subpleural and is caused by pulmonary hemorrhage or infarction. The appearance is often wedge-shaped; however, it can alternatively be dome-shaped, if the apex is spared as a result of collateral bronchial arterial blood flow.

The differential diagnosis includes pneumonia and malignancy. Of note, the greater distance between the spinous processes and the medial edge of the clavicle on the right compared to the left indicates that the patient is rotated slightly to the right. The distances will be nearly equal when a patient is not rotated, whereas widening will be seen on the side to which a patient is rotated.

Dashed lines: margins of medial clavicles; White line and ellipses: spinous processes

F) INCORRECT:

Smoking is an important risk factor for pulmonary emphysema, which causes dyspnea and fatigue. However, the symptoms of emphysema typically evolve over months and years rather than a few days. Moreover, the characteristic CXR findings for emphysema are increased lung lucency and flattening of the diaphragm due to hyperinflation. This patient's CXR findings are inconsistent with pulmonary emphysema.
Image Description:

X-ray chest (PA view) of a patient with a history of emphysema

The lungs are hyperlucent, with diaphragmatic flattening (indicated by dashed lines and arrows) and widening of the costophrenic sulci (indicated by white lines). The findings are consistent with air trapping.

An additional finding is asymmetry of the lung apices with slightly increased opacification in the left apex (red overlay) compared to the right. The chronicity cannot be determined from this single study, and the differential for chronic causes includes both scar and malignancy. A second small indeterminate opacity projects in the lower left lung (green overlay).

G) INCORRECT:

Certain infectious causes of interstitial pneumonia (e.g., Mycoplasma pneumonia, Pneumocystis pneumonia) lead to acute onset dyspnea, fatigue, and perihilar interstitial infiltrates. However, blunting of the costophrenic angle (due to pleural effusion) is uncommon in both Mycoplasma and Pneumocystis pneumonia, and features such as cardiomegaly and Kerley B lines would not be expected in interstitial pneumonia.
Image Description:

X-ray chest (A: PA view; B: lateral view) of a patient with Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia

Bilateral airspace and interstitial opacities are predominant in the perihilar regions of both lungs, in the left greater than the right (examples indicated by green overlay). The heart size is normal and there are no pleural effusions.

H) INCORRECT:

An acute exacerbation of bronchial asthma can cause acute onset dyspnea, and the CXR would be normal or show evidence of hyperinflation (e.g., increased lung lucency, flattening of the diaphragm). This patient's CXR findings are inconsistent with bronchial asthma.
Image Description:

Chest x-ray (PA view)

Large lung volumes (green outline and arrows) are accompanied by intercostal space widening (examples indicated by red arrows) and diaphragmatic flattening, indicating hyperinflation.

I) INCORRECT:

Smoking is an important risk factor for idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis (IPF), which can cause dyspnea and reticular opacification. However, the symptoms of IPF typically evolve over months and years rather than a few days. In addition, the reticular opacification of IPF manifests with honeycombing of the lung, and it typically affects the base of the lungs, unlike the butterfly-shaped perihilar reticular opacities seen here. Moreover, the CXR findings of Kerley B lines and blunting of the costophrenic angle are inconsistent with IPF.
Image Description:

X-ray chest (posteroanterior view) of a patient with chronic progressive shortness of breath

Coarse reticular opacities (examples indicated by blue circles) in both lungs show a basal predominant distribution. The cardiac silhouette is enlarged and midline sternotomy wires (example of sternal wire indicated by black outline) and surgical clips (red lines) are evidence of prior coronary artery bypass grafting; however, there are no supportive findings for cardiogenic pulmonary edema, such as Kerley lines or pleural effusions.

CT was subsequently performed and showed peripheral honeycombing diagnostic of a usual-interstitial-pneumonia pattern. The patient was diagnosed with idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis (green overlay).
questions.hint: This patient's chest x-ray (CXR) shows butterfly-shaped perihilar opacification, Kerley B lines, cardiomegaly, and blunting of the costophrenic angle.

questions.text:
A 48-year-old woman with hypothyroidism and a history of nonischemic cardiomyopathy is hospitalized with acute heart failure. She received a primary-prevention implantable cardioverter-defibrillator one year ago. An echocardiogram one month ago documented a left ventricular ejection fraction of 20%. She weighs 80 kg.
Her current medications are carvedilol 6.25 mg twice daily, lisinopril 20 mg daily, spironolactone 25 mg daily, furosemide 120 mg twice daily, and levothyroxine 125 μg daily. The doses of her medications have not been adjusted recently.
Initial laboratory testing reveals a serum potassium level of 3.6 mEq/liter (reference range, 3.5–5.0), a serum creatinine level of 2.1 mg/dL (compared with a baseline level of 1.2 mg/dL four months ago; reference range, 0.6–1.1), and a thyroid-stimulating hormone concentration of 2.8 μU/mL (0.5–4.7).
The lisinopril and spironolactone are discontinued, and the patient is initially managed with intravenous furosemide boluses, scheduled three times a day, and combination low-dose hydralazine and isosorbide dinitrate.
On hospital day 3, she has a blood pressure of 95/74 mm Hg, a heart rate of 106 beats per minute, an oxygen saturation of 96% on 4 liters of oxygen via nasal cannula, and a declining urine output despite the increased doses of intravenous furosemide. She appears slightly fatigued, she has inspiratory rales, and her extremities are cool to the touch.
Which one of the following next steps is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Restart carvedilol at an increased dose

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Restarting lisinopril may worsen kidney function in a patient who has features of poor renal perfusion and is at risk for acute kidney injury.

B) CORRECT:

This patient with severely depressed left ventricular systolic function has been hospitalized with acute heart failure, is not responding to intravenous loop diuretics, and has evidence of poor organ perfusion (oliguria and cool extremities) — raising concern for cardiogenic shock.

For patients with cardiogenic shock, the 2022 American College of Cardiology/American Heart Association guidelines on heart failure recommend temporary support with an intravenous inotropic agent, such as dobutamine, to maintain systemic perfusion and preserve end-organ performance until definitive therapy is instituted or until the acute precipitating problem resolves. An intravenous inotrope is appropriate for a patient with severely depressed systolic function, marginal cardiac output, and fluid overload who responds poorly to intravenous diuretics or has worsening renal function.

Dobutamine, a positive inotropic agent and beta-1-adrenergic receptor agonist, has been used intravenously to treat patients with acute heart failure and as a bridge to transplantation. Short-term use of this agent has been shown to provide symptomatic improvement in these patients.

Key learning point: The most appropriate class of medications for a patient who is hospitalized with acute decompensated heart failure, severely depressed left ventricular systolic function, low cardiac output, and evidence of poor renal perfusion and who is not responding to intravenous loop diuretics is an inotropic agent.

C) INCORRECT:

The addition of metolazone can augment diuresis of a loop diuretic, but in a patient with evidence of poor renal perfusion, the first step is to improve cardiac output and perfusion to the kidneys. Metolazone is only available as a tablet; it is not administered intravenously.

D) INCORRECT:

Spironolactone may be helpful as long-term therapy, but it increases the risk for hyperkalemia in patients with impaired renal perfusion.

E) INCORRECT:

Increasing the dose of the beta-blocker (carvedilol) in a patient with acute decompensated heart failure could worsen cardiac output and potentiate cardiogenic shock.

questions.text:
A 68-year-old woman reports 3 weeks of worsening shortness of breath, diminished urine output, progressive nausea, and abdominal fullness. She has a history of chemotherapy-induced cardiomyopathy, with a left ventricular ejection fraction of 25%.
On admission, she is afebrile, her heart rate is regular at 110 beats per minute, and her blood pressure is 89/54 mm Hg. She has an elevated jugular venous pressure at 13 cm of water, pulmonary crackles, 2+ pitting lower-extremity edema, cool extremities, abdominal fullness with mild right-upper- quadrant tenderness, and a palpable liver edge.
Her serum creatinine concentration has increased from a baseline measurement of 0.8 mg/dL to a current level of 2.5 mg/dL (reference range, 0.6–1.1).
Other notable laboratory findings are as follows:



Patient value
Reference range


Potassium (mEq/liter)
5.7
3.5–5.0


Alanine aminotransferase (U/liter)
256
0–35


Aspartate aminotransferase (U/liter)
325
0–35


Lactate (mmol/liter)
0.7
0.6–1.7


Total bilirubin (mg/dL)
0.7
0.3–1.0


Alkaline phosphatase (U/liter)
110
30–120


Which one of the following initial management approaches is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Saline is reserved for hypotensive patients with volume depletion as the cause of their renal insufficiency. This patient’s renal insufficiency is related to poor forward cardiac output. Intravenous fluids would only exacerbate this patient’s congestion and should be kept to a minimum; hypotension should be treated with intravenous inotropic agents.

B) INCORRECT:

Urgent CT of the abdomen might be performed to direct a surgical intervention if the patient had a possible intra-abdominal process as the cause of her hypotension. However, an ultrasound would be a safer and more sensitive test if a biliary process were suspected, and abdominal CT might require administration of contrast for optimal visualization of abdominal structures.

C) INCORRECT:

An ultrasound of the right upper quadrant is appropriate for a patient with abnormal results on liver function tests when the cause is unknown. However, this patient’s elevated aminotransferase levels can be attributed to hepatic congestion, and her normal bilirubin and alkaline phosphatase levels make acute cholecystitis less likely.

D) INCORRECT:

Although this patient has pulmonary congestion and acute kidney injury, she does not require renal replacement therapy, and her hypotension likely precludes hemodialysis. A randomized trial showed that a stepped pharmacologic approach was superior to ultrafiltration for preserving kidney function, that both strategies were similar in the amount of fluid removal, and that ultrafiltration was associated with a higher rate of adverse events.

E) CORRECT:

This patient with heart failure is presenting with features of both volume overload and poor perfusion. Clinical features of volume overload include elevated jugular venous pressure, lower-extremity edema, pulmonary crackles, an S3 gallop, and elevated aminotransferase levels secondary to hepatic congestion. Signs and symptoms consistent with low perfusion include poor mentation, cool extremities, and anion-gap lactic-metabolic acidosis.

The presence of both clinical evidence of volume overload (suggesting a high preload) and low perfusion at rest (suggesting a low stroke volume) in a patient with heart failure suggests that the patient is past the point of overstretch of the myocardium. This can be illustrated by the Frank-Starling curves, which illustrate the relationship between preload and stroke volume in various states of contractility and the effect of possible interventions.

Patients who have both volume overload and low perfusion at rest are most appropriately treated with an inotropic agent to improve tissue perfusion and diuresis. Intravenous vasodilators are another option for improving cardiac output and perfusion, but their use is more limited in patients who are already hypotensive (as in this case).

Although this patient has pulmonary congestion and acute kidney injury, she does not require renal replacement therapy, and her hypotension likely precludes hemodialysis. A randomized trial showed that a stepped pharmacologic approach was superior to ultrafiltration for preserving kidney function, that both strategies were similar in the amount of fluid removal, and that ultrafiltration was associated with a higher rate of adverse events. Appropriate inotropic therapy is the best initial therapy because it may improve this patient’s kidney function, thereby obviating the need for invasive measures.

Key learning point: Patients with heart failure who are hospitalized with evidence of low perfusion should be treated with intravenous inotropic therapy.
Image Description:

The Frank-Starling mechanism maintains cardiac output by increasing myocardial contractility in response to an increased preload (end-diastolic volume).

The Frank-Starling mechanism maintains cardiac output by increasing myocardial contractility and thus stroke volume, in response to an increased preload (end-diastolic volume). The autonomic nervous system is able to regulate the heart rate as well as cardiac excitability, conductivity, relaxation, and contractility.

questions.text:
A 63-year-old man who has a history of hypertension, heart failure with reduced ejection fraction (HFrEF), hyperlipidemia, type 2 diabetes, chronic kidney disease, and obesity is hospitalized for worsening dyspnea on exertion. His medications include lisinopril, carvedilol, atorvastatin, furosemide, and metformin. One week ago, he noticed that he had gained 2 kg during the preceding week. After discussing this with his primary care provider, he doubled his furosemide from 40 mg daily to 80 mg daily. Increasing the furosemide did not improve his symptoms, and he reports less urine volume than usual.
On examination, his blood pressure is 150/88 mm Hg, his heart rate is 72 beats per minute, his weight is 120 kg (up from 117 kg 2 weeks ago), his respiratory rate is 22 breaths per minute, and his oxygen saturation is 93% while he breathes ambient air. He is in mild respiratory distress. He has jugular venous distention to the angle of the mandible and crackles in both lungs. Cardiac auscultation reveals an intermittent third heart sound, with regular rate and rhythm and no murmur. Hepatojugular reflux is positive, with mild hepatomegaly and 1+ pitting edema up to his knees. His extremities are warm and without cyanosis.
Laboratory findings are as follows:



Patient value
Reference range


Hemoglobin (g/dL)
13.2
13.5–17.5


Creatinine (mg/dL)
3.4 (baseline, 2.1)
0.8–1.3


Blood urea nitrogen (mg/dL)
96
10–20


Potassium (mEq/liter)
5.2
3.5–5.0


Sodium (mEq/liter)
126
136–145


Brain natriuretic peptide (pg/mL)
1550
≤56


An electrocardiogram documents sinus rhythm with left ventricular hypertrophy and no evidence of ischemia. Echocardiography is pending.
What is the most appropriate next step in management for this patient?

choices.text: Continue oral diuretics, but double the dose

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This patient presents with type 1 cardiorenal syndrome, a condition in which symptoms of heart failure are accompanied by declining renal function, manifested by an increase in serum creatinine levels. Diuretics, particularly loop diuretics, are the first-line treatment for decompensated heart failure, regardless of renal function. In some patients, initial treatment may further worsen renal function, possibly because of a transient reduction in cardiac output as filling pressures drop. However, this should not deter clinicians from addressing the volume overload with diuretics.

Higher doses of diuretics may be required in the setting of acute decompensated heart failure because of an increase in renal sodium avidity. Furosemide has poor and variable oral bioavailability. In addition, in this setting, bowel edema or decreased duodenal blood flow may limit absorption, and this may be the reason that the patient did not respond to an increased dose of furosemide. Thus, an intravenous strategy is preferred to start. Intravenous diuretics should be given (as a bolus or continuous infusion) at a dose equal to or exceeding that taken by mouth, with frequent reassessment of weight loss, symptoms, and hemodynamic stability — and redosing as needed. Once the patient is stable, an appropriate oral dose can be identified.

Key learning point: A patient with acute decompensated heart failure and acute-on-chronic kidney disease who appears to have adequate perfusion and is hemodynamically stable should be started on intravenous diuretics, regardless of renal function.

B) INCORRECT:

Furosemide has poor and variable oral bioavailability. In addition, in this setting, bowel edema or decreased duodenal blood flow may limit absorption, and this may be the reason that the patient did not respond to an increased dose of furosemide.

C) INCORRECT:

Management of hypervolemic hyponatremia in a patient with heart failure and acute volume overload should be diuresis. Tolvaptan is one of the arginine vasopressin antagonists available for treating hyponatremia; however, its long-term benefits and safety are unknown.

D) INCORRECT:

Starting treatment with ultrafiltration without first trying intravenous diuretics is not appropriate. If the patient does not respond to an intravenous diuretic and escalation of the diuretic therapy, then the patient would be classified as diuretic resistant, and ultrafiltration with or without vasodilators could be considered as the next management strategy.

E) INCORRECT:

Starting treatment with inotrope without first trying intravenous diuretics is not appropriate. If the patient does not respond to an intravenous diuretic and escalation of the diuretic therapy, then the patient would be classified as diuretic resistant, and low-dose inotropes with or without vasodilators could be considered as the next management strategy.

questions.text:
An 82-year-old man with a history of hypertension, chronic kidney disease, and hypothyroidism presents for management of heart failure. He has stable, two-pillow orthopnea. During the past 4 months, he has experienced worsening dyspnea when walking 25 to 100 feet.
He was diagnosed with nonischemic cardiomyopathy 10 years ago, when cardiac catheterization with coronary angiography revealed no obstructive coronary artery disease. He has a 10-pack-year history of smoking but quit 40 years ago. He says he does not snore when he sleeps.
His current medications are levothyroxine 75 μg daily, carvedilol 12.5 mg twice daily, losartan 50 mg daily, hydralazine 25 mg twice daily, furosemide 80 mg twice daily, and potassium chloride 20 mEq twice daily.
His heart rate is 98 beats per minute, his blood pressure is 105/67 mm Hg, and his oxygen saturation is 95% while he is breathing ambient air. His weight is stable at 90 kg, and his BMI is 24. His jugular venous pressure is estimated at 9 cm. He has a regular heart rate and rhythm with a laterally displaced point of maximal impulse. He also has a 3/6 systolic murmur; P2 is prominent. His lungs have minimal crackles on auscultation. He has mild lower-extremity edema to his knees.
Laboratory findings include a stable creatinine concentration of 2.8 mg/dL (reference range, 0.8–1.3) and a brain natriuretic peptide level of 834 pg/mL (≤91).
Which one of the following evaluations of this patient’s dyspnea is most appropriate?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A bubble study may help to diagnose an interatrial connection. A patent foramen ovale rarely leads to left-to-right shunting and pulmonary hypertension. There is little to suggest shunt physiology in this patient who is not hypoxemic.

B) INCORRECT:

CT of the chest can be useful if lung pathology, such as interstitial lung disease, is suspected, but his patient’s features and findings are not consistent with a primary pulmonary process.

C) INCORRECT:

Pulmonary function testing may reveal a reduction in carbon monoxide-diffusing lung capacity or FEV1, but the findings would be nonspecific if the primary process appears to be cardiogenic.

D) INCORRECT:

Although right heart catheterization is needed for the diagnosis of pulmonary arterial hypertension, it is not required in World Health Organization group 2 pulmonary hypertension (pulmonary hypertension caused by left ventricular dysfunction). In that setting, the priority is to treat the left heart failure.

E) CORRECT:

Pulmonary venous hypertension can develop as a sequela of chronically elevated left-sided filling pressures. Chronically elevated left ventricular filling pressures and volume overload passively increase pulmonary venous pressures, eventually leading to pulmonary venous hypertension. That, in turn, can be associated with elevated right ventricular pressures and right ventricular dysfunction. Treatment includes diuretics to reduce volume overload and focused treatment of left-sided heart disease. Early diagnosis, followed by aggressive management of heart failure and volume overload, can slow or halt this process.

Echocardiography can detect elevated pulmonary venous pressure, which is suspected in this patient, as well as assess for progression of left ventricular dysfunction. It also allows for evaluation for new valvular disease, which may contribute to worsening heart failure.

Key learning point: Evaluation of a patient with chronic heart failure, a prominent P2, and worsening dyspnea should include an echocardiogram to evaluate worsening left ventricular function and secondary pulmonary hypertension.

questions.text: A 58-year-old man comes to the office because of a 5-day history of progressively worsening shortness of breath and fatigue. His pulse is 96/min, respirations are 26/min, and blood pressure is 100/60 mm Hg. An x-ray of the chest is shown. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's findings?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This patient's acute onset dyspnea and CXR findings suggest cardiogenic pulmonary edema due to left ventricular failure. Individuals with left ventricular failure initially develop interstitial edema, which results in smooth reticular opacification and Kerley B lines due to accentuation of the vascular markings. With the further increase in pulmonary capillary wedge pressure, individuals can develop features of alveolar edema (e.g., consolidation with an air bronchogram) and pleural effusion (e.g., blunting of the costophrenic angle). In pulmonary edema, the opacification can often assume a perihilar distribution (a so-called “batwing” or “butterfly-shaped” pattern), which is seen here, because the periphery of the lung has better lymphatic drainage than the central regions.

Key learning point: Left ventricular failure causes cardiogenic pulmonary edema, seen on chest x-ray as perihilar "batwing" opacities, Kerley B lines, cardiomegaly, and pleural effusions.

B) INCORRECT:

Tricuspid regurgitation is a rare valvular condition. It typically manifests with clinical features of right heart failure, such as jugular venous distention, pulsatile hepatomegaly, and pedal edema, none of which are seen here. Moreover, the CXR findings for tricuspid regurgitation typically include right atrial and right ventricular enlargement, unlike the left ventricular enlargement seen on this patient's CXR.
Image Description:

X-ray chest (PA view) of a neonate with Ebstein anomaly

The cardiac silhouette is markedly enlarged. Prominent convexity of the right heart border (green line) is the result of caudal displacement of the tricuspid valve with atrialization of the right ventricle and tricuspid regurgitation. The central pulmonary arteries (green arrowheads) and aortic knob (red arrowhead) are diminutive in appearance. An endotracheal tube is present, along with an umbilical venous catheter and nasogastric tube.

Radiographic findings in Ebstein anomaly may vary with the severity of the condition.

C) INCORRECT:

Spontaneous pneumothorax causes acute onset dyspnea, and a CXR would show a radiolucent region without lung markings (air collection). This patient's CXR findings are inconsistent with a pneumothorax.
Image Description:

Chest x-ray (PA view) of a patient without a history of trauma

A large left pneumothorax (blue overlay) is seen, with an absence of lung markings peripheral to the collapsed lung (yellow overlay). Contralateral shift of the mediastinum (indicated by arrows) has resulted in a prominent right heart border (white line), and there is slight widening of the left lateral costophrenic angle (angle marker). These findings are consistent with tension pneumothorax. Incidentally noted is a mild rotatory curvature of the upper thoracic spine.

The absence of thoracic trauma suggests a spontaneous pneumothorax.

Dashed white line: visceral pleural line; green overlay: spinous process; red overlay: vertebral pedicles

D) INCORRECT:

Pulmonary emphysema manifests with dyspnea and fatigue. However, the symptoms of emphysema typically evolve over months and years rather than a few days. Moreover, the characteristic CXR findings for emphysema are increased lung lucency and flattening of the diaphragm due to hyperinflation. This patient's CXR findings are inconsistent with pulmonary emphysema.
Image Description:

X-ray chest (PA view) of a patient with a history of emphysema

The lungs are hyperlucent, with diaphragmatic flattening (indicated by dashed lines and arrows) and widening of the costophrenic sulci (indicated by white lines). The findings are consistent with air trapping.

An additional finding is asymmetry of the lung apices with slightly increased opacification in the left apex (red overlay) compared to the right. The chronicity cannot be determined from this single study, and the differential for chronic causes includes both scar and malignancy. A second small indeterminate opacity projects in the lower left lung (green overlay).

E) INCORRECT:

Certain infectious causes of interstitial pneumonia (e.g., Mycoplasma pneumonia, Pneumocystis pneumonia) lead to acute onset dyspnea, fatigue, and perihilar interstitial infiltrates. However, blunting of the costophrenic angle (due to pleural effusion) is uncommon in both Mycoplasma and Pneumocystis pneumonia, and features such as cardiomegaly and Kerley B lines would not be expected in interstitial pneumonia.
Image Description:

X-ray chest (A: PA view; B: lateral view) of a patient with Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia

Bilateral airspace and interstitial opacities are predominant in the perihilar regions of both lungs, in the left greater than the right (examples indicated by green overlay). The heart size is normal and there are no pleural effusions.
questions.hint: This patient's chest x-ray (CXR) shows butterfly-shaped perihilar opacification, Kerley B lines, cardiomegaly, and blunting of the costophrenic angle.

questions.text:
An 80-year-old man presents to the Emergency Department with severe shortness of breath and orthopnea that started recently. He has a history of chronic systolic dysfunction and has not taken his usual medications for several weeks. Examination reveals elevated jugular venous pressure, an S3 gallop, bilateral crackles on lung auscultation, and 2+ pitting edema on the lower extremities (see report).


Heart rate
110/min


Blood pressure
145/90 mmHg


Oxygen saturation
88% on room air


Chest X-ray: Vascular congestion
Which of the following is the most appropriate immediate intervention?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

The patient exhibits acute decompensated heart failure with volume overload, indicated by severe dyspnea, orthopnea, elevated jugular venous pressure, S3 gallop, bilateral crackles, and peripheral edema. Chest X-ray shows vascular congestion, confirming pulmonary fluid accumulation. Intravenous loop diuretics, such as furosemide, provide rapid relief by promoting diuresis, reducing intravascular volume, and decreasing pulmonary capillary pressures. This intervention alleviates pulmonary edema and improves respiratory status quickly, addressing the underlying pathophysiology of volume overload.

Key learning point: In the immediate management of heart failure with fluid overload, loop diuretics like furosemide are used to rapidly reduce excess fluid and relieve symptoms such as pulmonary congestion and peripheral edema.

B) INCORRECT:

Urgent coronary angiography is indicated for suspected acute coronary syndrome, characterized by chest pain, ischemic ECG changes, or elevated cardiac biomarkers. This patient shows signs of fluid overload due to medication nonadherence, not a new ischemic event.

C) INCORRECT:

Beta-blockers are contraindicated in acute decompensated heart failure due to their negative inotropic effects, which can worsen cardiac output and pulmonary congestion. The patient presents with volume overload and reduced oxygen saturation, requiring immediate preload reduction rather than heart rate control.

D) INCORRECT:

Synthetic catecholamines such as dobutamine are used for cardiogenic shock or low-output states with hypotension. This patient has volume overload with elevated blood pressure, indicating fluid retention rather than low cardiac output. Dobutamine may increase myocardial oxygen consumption and tachycardia without addressing fluid overload.

questions.text:
A 78-year-old man presents with a 3-day history of progressively worsening shortness of breath. He has a 10-year history of hypertension and a recent diagnosis of heart failure with preserved ejection fraction. He has gained 3 kg in the past week. Examination shows jugular venous pressure elevated at 4 cm above the sternal angle, bilateral crackles to the mid-lung fields, and peripheral edema up to the mid-calves (see lab results and report).


Respiratory rate
25/min


Oxygen saturation
88% on room air




Test
Result
Normal Values



Creatinine
120 μmol/L
44 - 115 μmol/L


Brain natriuretic peptide
150 ng/L
0 - 100 ng/L



Echocardiogram: Left ventricular ejection fraction of 50%
Which of the following is the most appropriate initial management step?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Sodium nitroprusside is a potent vasodilator used in hypertensive emergencies or heart failure with severe hypertension. This patient presents with volume overload in HFpEF, not severe hypertension. Nitroprusside's rapid blood pressure reduction risks hypotension, especially in elderly patients with borderline renal perfusion.

B) CORRECT:

Heart failure with preserved ejection fraction (HFpEF) involves diastolic dysfunction, leading to increased left ventricular filling pressures. This patient exhibits signs of acute volume overload, including rapid weight gain, elevated jugular venous pressure, pulmonary crackles, and peripheral edema. Intravenous loop diuretics provide rapid natriuresis and diuresis, reducing preload and alleviating both pulmonary and systemic congestion. This intervention is crucial in symptomatic decompensation with compromised oxygenation. Monitoring renal function is essential due to potential interactions between renal impairment and diuretic therapy.

Key learning point: In acute decompensated heart failure with preserved ejection fraction, the primary management goal is to relieve congestion and fluid overload, typically achieved with diuretics like furosemide.

C) INCORRECT:

Milrinone, a phosphodiesterase inhibitor, enhances contractility and reduces afterload, benefiting patients with systolic dysfunction or cardiogenic shock. This patient, however, has HFpEF, characterized by diastolic dysfunction and volume overload, not reduced contractility. Milrinone does not address the primary issue of volume overload in HFpEF.

D) INCORRECT:

Beta blockers are crucial in chronic heart failure management but are inappropriate in acute decompensation with volume overload. They reduce myocardial contractility, potentially worsening cardiac output and perfusion in acute states. This patient requires therapies that rapidly reduce preload and alleviate congestion.

questions.text: A 58-year-old man comes to your clinic with a 5-day history of progressively worsening shortness of breath and fatigue. His pulse is 96/min, respirations are 26/min, and blood pressure is 100/60 mm Hg. A chest x-ray is provided. Which one of the following is the most likely cause of his findings?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This patient's acute onset dyspnea and CXR findings suggest cardiogenic pulmonary edema due to left ventricular failure. Individuals with left ventricular failure initially develop interstitial edema, which results in smooth reticular opacification and Kerley B lines due to accentuation of the vascular markings. With the further increase in pulmonary capillary wedge pressure, individuals can develop features of alveolar edema (e.g., consolidation with an air bronchogram) and pleural effusion (e.g., blunting of the costophrenic angle). In pulmonary edema, the opacification can often assume a perihilar distribution (a so-called “batwing” or “butterfly-shaped” pattern), which is seen here, because the periphery of the lung has better lymphatic drainage than the central regions.

Key learning point: Left ventricular failure commonly causes cardiogenic pulmonary edema, seen on chest x-ray as perihilar opacities, Kerley B lines, and possible pleural effusions due to increased pulmonary capillary wedge pressure.

B) INCORRECT:

Certain infectious causes of interstitial pneumonia (e.g., Mycoplasma pneumonia, Pneumocystis pneumonia) lead to acute onset dyspnea, fatigue, and perihilar interstitial infiltrates. However, blunting of the costophrenic angle (due to pleural effusion) is uncommon in both Mycoplasma and Pneumocystis pneumonia, and features such as cardiomegaly and Kerley B lines would not be expected in interstitial pneumonia.

C) INCORRECT:

Pulmonary emphysema manifests with dyspnea and fatigue. However, the symptoms of emphysema typically evolve over months and years rather than a few days. Moreover, the characteristic CXR findings for emphysema are increased lung lucency and flattening of the diaphragm due to hyperinflation. This patient's CXR findings are inconsistent with pulmonary emphysema.

D) INCORRECT:

Spontaneous pneumothorax causes acute onset dyspnea, and a CXR would show a radiolucent region without lung markings (air collection). This patient's CXR findings are inconsistent with a pneumothorax.

E) INCORRECT:

Tricuspid regurgitation is a rare valvular condition. It typically manifests with clinical features of right heart failure, such as jugular venous distention, pulsatile hepatomegaly, and pedal edema, none of which are seen here. Moreover, the CXR findings for tricuspid regurgitation typically include right atrial and right ventricular enlargement, unlike the left ventricular enlargement seen on this patient's CXR.
questions.hint: This patient's chest x-ray (CXR) shows butterfly-shaped perihilar opacification, Kerley B lines, cardiomegaly, and blunting of the costophrenic angle.

questions.text: A 78-year-old woman with a history of heart failure and permanent atrial fibrillation presents with 2 days of worsening dyspnea and productive cough. Vital signs are BP, 88/52; P, 118; R, 28; T, 38.9°C (102.0°F); oxygen saturation, 92% on room air. Physical examination shows jugular venous distension, bilateral rales, and 2+ lower extremity edema. Laboratory studies show WBC 18,500/μL, platelets 98 × 103/mm3, lactate 3.2 mEq/L, bilirubin 1.3 mg/dL, and creatinine 1.4 mg/dL. Chest x-ray shows right lower lobe consolidation and pulmonary vascular congestion. ECG is shown. Which of the following is the best next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Beta blockers should not be initiated in patients with acute decompensated heart failure, especially in patients with hemodynamic instability, because they can worsen cardiac output and blood pressure.

B) INCORRECT:

While diuretics are typically used in heart failure management, this patient is hemodynamically unstable. Diuretics would further reduce intravascular volume and worsen hypotension, potentially compromising organ perfusion.

C) INCORRECT:

SGLT2 inhibitors such as empagliflozin are used in the treatment of heart failure but should only be initiated when patients are hemodynamically stable.

D) INCORRECT:

Sodium nitroprusside reduces both preload and afterload and is useful in acute heart failure with severe hypertension. However, it is contraindicated in this hypotensive patient, as further vasodilation would worsen hypotension and compromise organ perfusion.

E) CORRECT:

Correct – This patient presents with sepsis from pneumonia that has precipitated acute decompensated heart failure and is hemodynamically unstable. Treating the underlying infection with antibiotics is the priority, as this addresses the precipitating factor for the heart failure exacerbation. Blood cultures should be obtained before starting antibiotics.

questions.text: A 68-year-old man presents with progressive dyspnea and orthopnea over 3 days. Physical examination shows jugular venous distension, bilateral lower extremity edema, and bibasilar crackles. BNP is 650 pg/mL, and troponin is 0.02 ng/mL. ECG shows sinus tachycardia with nonspecific ST-T wave changes. Chest x-ray shows cardiomegaly and pulmonary congestion. What is the best next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Beta blockers are contraindicated in acute decompensated heart failure and should not be initiated during acute exacerbations.

B) INCORRECT:

While morphine is used in some settings to relieve respiratory distress, it is not recommended in acute heart failure management.

C) CORRECT:

Correct -- This patient has acute heart failure with volume overload and elevated BNP. Intravenous loop diuretics are the immediate treatment for acute decompensated heart failure with volume overload.

D) INCORRECT:

ACE inhibitors are used in chronic heart failure management but are not the immediate priority in acute decompensated heart failure with volume overload.

E) INCORRECT:

Cardiac catheterization is not indicated as immediate management for acute heart failure. This patient's normal troponin and nonspecific ECG changes do not suggest acute coronary syndrome requiring urgent catheterization.

questions.text: A 62-year-old man with a history of anterior myocardial infarction presents with acute-onset dyspnea and fatigue. He appears anxious and diaphoretic with cool extremities. Vital signs are BP, 82/55; P, 105; R, 24; oxygen saturation, 90% on room air. Physical examination shows elevated jugular venous pressure and bilateral lower lobe crackles. Echocardiogram shows severely reduced left ventricular ejection fraction with no pericardial effusion. The patient has adequate urine output but requires 4 L of oxygen to maintain saturation above 90%. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Furosemide should not be initiated in hemodynamically unstable patients. In hypotensive patients with acute heart failure, hemodynamic support must be prioritized before diuretic therapy to prevent further reduction in cardiac output and worsening hypoperfusion.

B) INCORRECT:

IV fluid administration can worsen cardiogenic pulmonary edema in patients with evidence of congestion. This patient has clear signs of volume overload, including elevated jugular venous pressure, bilateral crackles, and oxygen requirement, making fluid resuscitation inappropriate and potentially harmful.

C) CORRECT:

Correct -- This patient presents with wet and cold acute heart failure based on evidence of congestion (elevated jugular venous pressure, bilateral crackles, oxygen requirement) and hypoperfusion (hypotension, cool extremities, diaphoresis). The initial management for wet and cold acute heart failure is inotropic support with dobutamine to improve cardiac contractility and increase cardiac output while maintaining perfusion pressure.

D) INCORRECT:

Vasopressors like norepinephrine primarily affect vascular tone and are only added if cardiogenic shock persists despite adequate inotropic support. The initial approach in wet and cold acute heart failure is inotropic therapy to improve cardiac contractility.

E) INCORRECT:

Nitroglycerin is contraindicated in patients with systolic blood pressure less than 90 mm Hg due to risk of further hypotension. Vasodilators are appropriate for hypertensive acute heart failure but are dangerous in hypotensive patients with cardiogenic shock.

questions.text: A 62-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by EMS after being found unconscious at home by a neighbor. The patient is minimally responsive and unable to provide history. Vital signs are BP, 82/50; P, 108; R, 20; T, 37.2°C (99.0°F); oxygen saturation, 98% on room air. Physical examination shows cool, mottled extremities with delayed capillary refill, clear lung sounds bilaterally, no jugular venous distension, and no peripheral edema. ECG shows sinus tachycardia without acute ST changes. The patient receives 500 mL of IV crystalloid fluids with no improvement in blood pressure or perfusion. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Additional fluid administration is not indicated in patients with cold and dry heart failure when there has been no improvement with initial fluid therapy.

B) INCORRECT:

Inotropic therapy is not first-line management in cold and dry heart failure presentations that are not responsive to fluids.

C) INCORRECT:

Inotropic therapy with milrinone is not the next best step in cold and dry heart failure presentations unresponsive to fluids.

D) CORRECT:

Correct -- Vasopressor therapy with norepinephrine is indicated in cold and dry heart failure presentations when shock persists after initial fluid resuscitation.

E) INCORRECT:

While vasopressors are indicated in cold and dry heart failure presentations not responsive to fluids, norepinephrine is preferred over epinephrine as first-line therapy.

questions.text: A 67-year-old patient with known systolic heart failure presents with worsening dyspnea over 2 days. Vital signs are BP, 88/54; P, 118; R, 26; oxygen saturation, 91% on room air. Physical examination shows cool extremities, delayed capillary refill, jugular venous distention, and bilateral pulmonary crackles. After obtaining IV access and administering supplemental oxygen, what is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Provide fluid bolus 500 mL normal saline

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

IV furosemide is inappropriate as initial therapy in this patient with hypotension and signs of hypoperfusion. Diuretics should be avoided until hemodynamic stability is achieved because they can worsen hypotension and organ perfusion.

B) INCORRECT:

Nitroglycerin is contraindicated in patients with hypotension because it causes vasodilation and can worsen hypotension.

C) INCORRECT:

Fluid bolus is inappropriate in this patient with clear evidence of volume overload (e.g., jugular venous distention, pulmonary crackles). Additional fluid can worsen pulmonary congestion without addressing the underlying contractility problem.

D) CORRECT:

Correct -- This patient presents with wet and cold acute heart failure (congestion with hypoperfusion). The combination of hypotension, cool extremities, delayed capillary refill, and volume overload requires inotropic support as the first-line therapy. Dobutamine improves cardiac contractility and cardiac output while maintaining adequate perfusion pressure.

E) INCORRECT:

Norepinephrine alone does not address the underlying poor cardiac contractility in this patient with acute heart failure. While vasopressors may be added if hypotension persists despite inotropic support, treatment with inotropes is the most appropriate next step in this patient.

questions.text: A 74-year-old man presents with acute dyspnea. Physical examination shows bilateral rales and lower extremity edema. Vital signs are BP, 108/65; P, 98; T, 37.2°C (99°F); R, 28; oxygen saturation, 84% on room air. Arterial blood gas shows pH 7.32, PCO2 48 mm Hg, and PO2 55 mm Hg. Chest x-ray shows pulmonary congestion with bilateral costophrenic angle blunting. CPAP and IV furosemide are initiated. After 20 minutes, the patient appears distressed. BP is 85/55 mm Hg and pulse is 118/min. Arterial blood gas shows pH 7.28, PCO2 55 mm Hg, and PO2 52 mm Hg. What is the most appropriate next step?

choices.text: Switch from CPAP to BiPAP therapy

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

While intubation is indicated, proceeding immediately without hemodynamic preparation in this hypotensive patient is inappropriate. Hemodynamic stabilization is required before intubation to prevent cardiovascular collapse.

B) INCORRECT:

This patient has persistent hypoxemia, worsening hypercarbia, and acidosis despite noninvasive positive-pressure ventilation. These findings are indications for invasive mechanical ventilation, making escalation to BiPAP inappropriate.

C) INCORRECT:

Continuous vasopressor infusion requires time to prepare and titrate, whereas this patient needs immediate hemodynamic support before urgent intubation. This approach would delay necessary airway management.

D) CORRECT:

Correct – Despite CPAP therapy, this patient has worsening hypoxemia, hypercarbia, and acidosis, and now meets criteria for intubation. Patients with hemodynamic deterioration and hypotension require stabilization with bolus-dose vasopressors before intubation.

E) INCORRECT:

This patient's small pleural effusions are unlikely to be the primary cause of the respiratory compromise. Immediate intubation for stabilization is required.

questions.text: A 72-year-old man with a history of ischemic cardiomyopathy presents with worsening dyspnea over the past 2 days. Vital signs are BP, 88/60; P, 115; oxygen saturation, 90% on room air. Physical examination shows elevated jugular venous pressure, bilateral lower extremity edema, and bibasilar crackles. The patient appears cold and diaphoretic with delayed capillary refill. What is the most appropriate initial step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Vasopressors are typically added only if shock is refractory to inotropic support. The initial approach in heart failure with pump dysfunction is to improve cardiac contractility with inotropes rather than increasing systemic vascular resistance, which can worsen cardiac function.

B) CORRECT:

Correct -- This patient presents with evidence of congestion (i.e., elevated jugular venous pressure, edema, crackles) and hypoperfusion (i.e., hypotension, cold skin, delayed capillary refill). This patient's wet and cold clinical presentation requires initial inotropic support to improve cardiac contractility and restore adequate perfusion before addressing congestion with diuretics.

C) INCORRECT:

While loop diuretics are essential for managing congestion in patients with heart failure, they should be initiated after hemodynamic stabilization. In patients with evidence of congestion and hypoperfusion, addressing the underlying pump failure with inotropic support takes priority to restore adequate perfusion.

D) INCORRECT:

Vasodilators are contraindicated if systolic blood pressure is below 90 mm Hg. This patient's hypotension makes nitroglycerin inappropriate because it would further reduce blood pressure and worsen hypoperfusion.

E) INCORRECT:

Fluid administration is inappropriate in patients with clear evidence of congestion. This patient has elevated jugular venous pressure, edema, and pulmonary crackles, indicating volume overload. Additional fluid would worsen congestion and potentially precipitate further respiratory compromise.

questions.text: A 71-year-old woman with a history of heart failure with reduced ejection fraction presents with 3 days of worsening dyspnea and productive cough. Vital signs are BP, 138/86; P, 115; T, 38.5°C (101.3°F); R, 22; oxygen saturation, 90% on room air. Physical examination shows jugular venous distention, bibasilar crackles, and 2+ pitting edema. Chest x-ray shows bilateral lower lobe opacities with cardiomegaly. What is the most appropriate next step?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

In acute decompensated heart failure, beta blockers should only be initiated after stabilization, when the patient is hemodynamically stable without significant congestion.

B) CORRECT:

Correct – This patient has acute decompensated heart failure precipitated by likely pneumonia (fever, productive cough, bilateral lower lobe opacities on chest x-ray). All hemodynamically stable patients with heart failure and evidence of congestion require IV diuretic therapy as first-line treatment to address volume overload. This patient should also be started on antibiotics for pneumonia.

C) INCORRECT:

Noninvasive positive pressure ventilation is indicated for hypertensive emergency with flash pulmonary edema or severe respiratory distress. This patient has moderate hypoxemia and only mildly elevated blood pressure.

D) INCORRECT:

IV nitroglycerin is indicated for hypertensive emergency with flash pulmonary edema or as an adjuvant to first-line therapy. Another step in management is indicated in this patient at this time.

E) INCORRECT:

While torsemide is a loop diuretic used in the treatment of heart failure, IV administration is preferred in acute decompensated heart failure.

questions.text: A 72-year-old man with ischemic cardiomyopathy is brought to the emergency department by his wife because of acute dyspnea and confusion. His vital signs are BP, 72/50; P, 120; R, 28; oxygen saturation, 87% on a 4 L nasal cannula. Physical examination shows cool extremities, jugular venous distension, and bilateral pulmonary rales. He is not oriented to person, place, or time. Laboratory studies show creatinine 2.3 mg/dL and lactate 3.8 mmol/L. He remains hypotensive and tachycardic after initial stabilization measures. What is the most appropriate disposition for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Correct – This patient is hemodynamically unstable and has respiratory failure and signs of end-organ hypoperfusion (altered mental status, acute kidney injury, elevated lactate levels) and therefore requires ICU admission.

B) INCORRECT:

Telemetry units are designed for patients who require cardiac rhythm monitoring but lack the intensive monitoring and intervention capabilities needed for this level of hemodynamic instability and end-organ dysfunction.

C) INCORRECT:

Medical floor admission is insufficient for managing the complex hemodynamic and respiratory support required in this critically ill patient with multiple organ system involvement.

D) INCORRECT:

Observation units provide short-term monitoring for less critically ill patients and lack the resources to manage hemodynamic instability and the potential need for inotropic and/or vasopressor support.

E) INCORRECT:

Emergency department observation is inappropriate for the ongoing management of this patient's complex condition, which requires specialized monitoring and interventions beyond what the emergency department can provide long-term.

questions.text: A 72-year-old woman presents with a 3-month history of progressive dyspnea on exertion and orthopnea. She also reports bilateral lower extremity swelling that worsens throughout the day. Her medical history is significant for long-standing hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. Her medications include lisinopril and metformin. On examination, her blood pressure is 152/88 mm Hg, and her pulse is 94/min. There are bibasilar crackles on lung auscultation, jugular venous distention to 8 cm, and 2+ pitting edema to the mid-calves. An echocardiogram shows a left ventricular ejection fraction of 55% with evidence of left ventricular hypertrophy. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial medication?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Metoprolol, a beta-blocker, is used in heart failure to control heart rate and blood pressure and has mortality benefits in heart failure with reduced ejection fraction. While it may be used for long-term management of this patient's hypertension, initiating it or increasing the dose during an acute decompensation with volume overload can be detrimental by reducing cardiac output and worsening congestion. The primary goal is diuresis, not negative chronotropy or inotropy.

B) INCORRECT:

Sacubitril/valsartan, an angiotensin receptor-neprilysin inhibitor (ARNI), is a foundational therapy for heart failure with reduced ejection fraction and has shown benefit in some patients with heart failure with preserved ejection fraction. However, it is not used for the acute management of volume overload. Patients should be hemodynamically stable and euvolemic before initiating an ARNI. The immediate priority is relieving this patient's congestive symptoms with diuresis.

C) INCORRECT:

Spironolactone, a mineralocorticoid receptor antagonist, has been shown to reduce hospitalizations in patients with heart failure with preserved ejection fraction. However, it is a weak diuretic and is not indicated for the initial, rapid management of significant volume overload. Its primary role is in long-term neurohormonal modulation and management of chronic heart failure after the patient has been stabilized and is closer to a euvolemic state.

D) CORRECT:

This patient presents with classic signs and symptoms of volume overload (dyspnea, orthopnea, crackles, jugular venous distention, and edema) in the setting of heart failure with preserved ejection fraction. Loop diuretics, such as furosemide, are the first-line therapy for managing congestive symptoms in all types of heart failure. By inhibiting the Na-K-2Cl cotransporter in the thick ascending limb of the loop of Henle, furosemide promotes potent diuresis. This action rapidly reduces intravascular volume, decreases cardiac preload, and alleviates both pulmonary and peripheral edema, providing prompt symptomatic relief. While other medications are important for long-term management, addressing the acute fluid overload is the immediate priority.

E) INCORRECT:

Dapagliflozin, a sodium-glucose cotransporter-2 (SGLT2) inhibitor, is a guideline-directed medical therapy for all types of heart failure, including heart failure with preserved ejection fraction, as it reduces hospitalizations. Although it has a mild diuretic effect, it is not potent enough to manage significant acute volume overload. SGLT2 inhibitors are initiated for long-term risk reduction, typically once the patient is stable and euvolemic.
questions.hint: This patient's clinical presentation is classic for de novo heart failure. The most pressing issue to address is her symptomatic volume overload.

questions.text: A 34-year-old man comes to the emergency department with a 2-week history of progressive shortness of breath and fatigue. He also has difficulty breathing when lying flat and has noticed swelling in his ankles. He reports a flu-like illness about a month ago that resolved without treatment. He has no significant past medical history. His temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), blood pressure is 105/70 mm Hg, pulse is 110/min, and respirations are 22/min. Physical examination shows jugular venous distention and bilateral pitting edema of the lower extremities. Auscultation shows bibasilar crackles and an S3 gallop. An echocardiogram shows global hypokinesis with an ejection fraction of 25%. In addition to diuretics, which of the following is the most appropriate therapy?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Although this patient's heart failure is likely due to a preceding viral illness, antiviral therapy with acyclovir and oseltamivir is generally not effective. The most common viral causes of myocarditis (e.g., enteroviruses, parvovirus B19) do not have specific antiviral treatments. Furthermore, by the time heart failure symptoms develop, the acute viral infection has typically resolved, and the damage is due to the subsequent inflammatory response.

B) INCORRECT:

Immunosuppressive therapy with corticosteroids or intravenous immunoglobulin might be considered for specific, noninfectious causes of myocarditis, such as giant cell myocarditis or sarcoidosis. However, for the most common cause, viral myocarditis, routine use of immunosuppression is not recommended and may even be harmful. The standard of care is supportive management and treatment of the resulting heart failure.

C) INCORRECT:

Non-dihydropyridine calcium channel blockers, such as diltiazem, have negative inotropic effects, meaning they weaken the contractility of the heart muscle. This property is detrimental in a patient with a severely reduced ejection fraction and is therefore contraindicated in heart failure with reduced ejection fraction. Aspirin is not indicated because there is no evidence of an ischemic cause for this patient's heart failure.

D) INCORRECT:

These anti-inflammatory agents are used to treat pericarditis. Although myocarditis can have a pericardial component (myopericarditis), nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) like ibuprofen are contraindicated in acute heart failure. NSAIDs can cause sodium and water retention, impair renal function, and antagonize the effects of diuretics, thereby worsening heart failure.

E) CORRECT:

Guideline-directed medical therapy for acute HFrEF includes a beta-blocker (e.g., metoprolol) and a renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system (RAAS) inhibitor, such as an angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitor like lisinopril. Beta-blockers counteract the detrimental effects of chronic sympathetic activation, while ACE inhibitors block angiotensin II production, reducing afterload and preload. Both classes of medications have been shown to reduce mortality and morbidity in HFrEF. They should be started at low doses once the patient is hemodynamically stable and titrated to target doses as tolerated.
questions.hint: This patient's presentation is consistent with acute heart failure with a reduced ejection fraction (HFrEF), likely from viral myocarditis. The cornerstone of management, once the patient is euvolemic, involves medications that block the neurohormonal systems responsible for disease progression.

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department for a week of progressive shortness of breath, fatigue, and swelling in his feet. He had a flu-like illness three weeks ago. He now has difficulty lying flat. He has no significant past medical history. His temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), blood pressure is 98/64 mm Hg, pulse is 125/min, and respirations are 28/min. Oxygen saturation is 91% on room air. Physical examination shows bibasilar crackles, an S3 gallop, and 2+ pitting edema to the mid-shins. His extremities are cool to the touch. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial pharmacologic intervention?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Digoxin is a cardiac glycoside with weak positive inotropic effects. While it has a role in heart failure, particularly for rate control in atrial fibrillation, it is not a first-line agent for acute cardiogenic shock. More potent agents are required to rapidly stabilize a patient with severe cardiac dysfunction and hypotension. Its onset of action is also slower than other intravenous agents.

B) INCORRECT:

Intravenous loop diuretics such as furosemide are essential for managing volume overload in heart failure. However, in a hypotensive patient with signs of hypoperfusion, aggressive diuresis as a first-line therapy can reduce preload, further decrease cardiac output, and worsen blood pressure. Hemodynamic support to improve cardiac function should be prioritized before or administered concurrently with diuresis.

C) INCORRECT:

Beta-blockers are a standard evidence-based therapy for chronic, stable heart failure. However, they are contraindicated in acute decompensated heart failure, particularly with cardiogenic shock. Their negative inotropic (decreased contractility) and negative chronotropic (decreased heart rate) effects further depress cardiac function and worsen the patient's hemodynamic instability.

D) INCORRECT:

Angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors such as lisinopril are a cornerstone of long-term management for heart failure with reduced ejection fraction. However, they are contraindicated in acute cardiogenic shock and hypotension. Their vasodilatory effects cause a dangerous drop in blood pressure, exacerbating end-organ hypoperfusion. These medications are typically initiated once the patient is hemodynamically stable.

E) CORRECT:
